title: 105_s620
content: The "Women's Investment and Savings Equity Act of 1997" allows individuals to make deductible IRA contributions without considering their spouse's participation in a pension plan. Additionally, individuals are permitted to make contributions during periods of maternity or paternity leave. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code allows participants on eligible maternity or paternity leave to make additional contributions to their plans. This amendment affects the qualification of trusts under various sections of the Code. Participants on eligible maternity or paternity leave can make additional elective deferrals to their plans. Contributions made during this leave period are not subject to certain limitations under the Internal Revenue Code. Participants on eligible maternity or paternity leave can make additional elective deferrals to their plans, which are not subject to certain limitations under the Internal Revenue Code. Contributions made during this leave period will be subject to specific rules prescribed by the Secretary for the year they relate to, and the plan will not be considered to fail meeting certain requirements under various sections of the Code. Participants on eligible maternity or paternity leave can make additional elective deferrals to their plans, which are not subject to certain limitations under the Internal Revenue Code. Employers are not required to make matching contributions for these additional deferrals, but if they choose to do so, specific rules apply, and the amount cannot exceed the maximum allowed under the plan. Participants on eligible maternity or paternity leave can make additional elective deferrals to their plans, subject to specific rules regarding the amount and timing of these deferrals. The plan must ensure that the amount of elective deferrals made during this leave period does not exceed the maximum allowed under the plan if the individual had made the deferrals during that time. Participants on eligible maternity or paternity leave can make additional elective deferrals to their plans, subject to specific rules regarding the amount and timing of these deferrals. Proper adjustments are made for elective deferrals actually made during the leave period. An employee may make an elective deferral within 3 years after the leave ends, and matching contributions must be made by the due date. The deferral for eligible maternity or paternity leave must be made by the due date for the employer's return in the taxable year. Eligible leave includes absence due to pregnancy, birth of a child, or adoption placement. The adoption of a child by an individual for caring purposes after birth or placement is limited to 12 months. Definitions include elective deferral, plan, and certain retroactive adjustments. The rules of subsection (u)(3) apply for certain retroactive adjustments and subsection (u)(4) applies to loan repayment suspensions during eligible maternity and paternity leave. Effective starting from January 1, 1998. Catchup contributions for families with children not covered by a pension plan. Catchup contributions for families with children not covered by a pension plan involve amending the Internal Revenue Code to allow eligible participants to make additional elective deferrals under their plan or arrangement. This includes specific provisions regarding qualified trusts, plans under sections 401(a) and 403(b), eligible deferred compensation plans under section 457, and meeting requirements of section 408(k) or (p). A plan must allow eligible participants to make additional elective deferrals in a catchup year, limited to the lesser of the amount allowed under the plan or a specified limit. In a catchup year, eligible participants can make additional elective deferrals limited by the plan or a specified limit. The excess is calculated as 120 percent of the dollar limitation under section 402(g), 408(p), or 457(b)(2)(A) for the applicable taxable year, minus any other elective deferrals made by the participant without regard to this subsection. Contributions are treated accordingly. In a catchup year, eligible participants can make additional elective deferrals limited by the plan or a specified limit. Contributions to a plan under paragraph (1) are not subject to certain limitations for the year they are made. Contributions to a plan under paragraph (1) are not subject to certain limitations for the year they are made, including matching contributions. In a catchup year, eligible participants can make additional elective deferrals limited by the plan or a specified limit. Matching contributions made during the year must comply with section 401(a)(4) requirements and not exceed the maximum amount allowed for elective deferrals without this subsection. Participants must certify to the plan administrator when making additional elective deferrals. An eligible participant can certify one or more catchup years, limited to a total number not exceeding the excess of years before the current year over years previously certified. An eligible participant in a plan is not considered to fail requirements due to relying on an incorrect certification unless the plan administrator knew or should have known it was wrong. The term 'eligible participant' refers to a plan participant who was not an active participant for any plan year before the current year. The subsection defines terms like 'elective deferral' and 'plan' for the purpose of the section. It also outlines rules for eligible participants in a plan. The amendment made by this section applies to contributions in taxable years beginning after December 31, 1997, with certain retroactive adjustments not required.
